I am legitimately mad. I'm 13 and i've spent about a week triying to figure out the average nth derivative of a function between x=a and x=b. The day I finally manage to figure it out, I also figure out this guy did it 4 years ago 😭

As a fun fact I discovered on that week, as long as you have the two points (a,f(a)) and (b, f(b)), you dont even need to know the function you are working with to calculate it's average derivative.
This also means that all functions that cross those two points will have the same average derivative between the two.

perhaps you didn't think of this, but the instant explanation I came up with for this is:
you already know the area under the graph because you did the integral, so the average value would be if that area were applied to a rectangle (of width dx) instead and you just took the height of it. that way, much like a normal average, you're taking a quantity of values, summing them all up so as to ignore the bounds between them, and then dividing how many there are in order to get what each of those values would be if they were all equal (and still added up to the same value)

Sinx は-cosxの微分であるから、それは-cosxの各点における傾きである。Average of sinxとは即ちAverage of slope for -cosxである。
ここで、-cosxのrange of inputs 0-Piにおける傾きの平均は-cos(Pi)と-cos(0)の2点を通る直線の傾きであると考えられないだろうか。
((d-cos(x1)/dx)+(d-cos(x2)/dx+•••)/(Pi/dx)=-cos(Pi)-(-cos(0))/Pi
—> (d-cos(x1)+(d-cos(x2)+•••)/(Pi)=-cos(Pi)-(-cos(0))/Piとなり正しい。

Here's a fun example, the distribution of ants among a colony with mass x milligrams between 1 and 5 milligrams is given by -16x^2+112x-96. What is the probability that an ant's mass is less than or equal to 3 milligrams?

It's the integral of -16x^2+112x-96 from 1 to 3 divided by its integral from 1 to 5. That gives the count of ants dividing the count of ants with mass 3mg or less. It turns out to be about 40%.

People get lost in the technical details and calculations. It needs be put as simply as below (perhaps needs correction, this is rough) and repeated as the student learns more and more about those details. Too many people go through the motions and have no freaking idea what they are actually doing because they've lost sight of it.

Differentiation: I have a function and I'm going to work out a formula for the rate of change - how much that function changes - at any given point. The rate of change on a graph is the tangent/slope of the graph.

Integration: I have a formula for how much a function is changing and I want to add up all those changes. If I'm adding up those changes between two points on the graph, it's a definite integral. This looks like the area under the curve between those points. You need to make sure that if the area is under the graph it is subtracted not added.

The "trick" to doing both is to take small slices of the change (slope in differentiation, area in integration) and look at what happens as those slices get closer and closer to zero (limit as delta x -> 0).

so to find average height on the bound of the derivative, you add up all the heights of the derivatives and divide by the number of derivatives, AKA adding up all of the 'slopes' and dividing by the 'number of slopes'

To get the average algebraically, you should recall the definition
integral from a to b of f(x) dx = lim as n -> inf of the sum from i=1 to n of f(x) delta-x
I know that's a mouthful, it would be much more clear with pretty graphics :)
Point is, you got a sum of f(x) values that you want to divide by n to get an average. So,
sum from i=1 to n of f(x)
over n
We want to get infinitely many samples so we add
lim as n -> inf of sum from i=1 to n of f(x)
over n
Then we note that delta-x = (b-a)/n, therefore n = (b-a)/delta-x and 1/n = delta-x/(b-a), so we substitute
lim as n -> inf of delta-x * sum from i=1 to n of f(x)
over (b-a)
Then we move the 1/(b-a) constant out and delta-x into the sum
lim as n -> inf of sum from i=1 to n of f(x) delta-x
over (b-a)
And bam, we get an integral!
1/(b-a) integral from a to b of f(x) dx

Another nice video!  BTW, another visual intuition for why the average value of a function is related to the area under its graph: Imagine the graph of the function being represented as a wavy column of sand (e.g., sandwiched between two glass sheets, close together).  If you were to shake this (or smooth it out with a level piece of wood), the sand would settle out to a horizontal line - representing the average value of the graph.  But this is just the area of the original graph (because the volume of the sand hasn't changed) - divided by the length of the base.

I found this "averaging of slopes" a little confusing. I found a simpler way to think about it from Prof. Gilbert Strang's video (https://goo.gl/qFFqW1). If a function f(x) is a derivative of another function F(x), then any point in its curve (=height) captures the changes in F(x) at that point. Therefore, the cumulative change in F(x) [=F(b)-F(a)] between points a and b will be equal to the sum of all the points on f(x) between those two points (=area under the curve). Now if we are able to find F(x) then we can find the area under the curve f(x) between any two points a and b by calculating F(b)-F(a). Hope you can incorporate some of this into the video if I make any sense. Needless to say, you do an amazing job with your videos! Thank you for all your contents.

At the end, if you take the formula: int_a^b (f(x) dx) / (b - a) = (F(b) - F(a)) / (b - a), and move b closer to a, then in the limit the LHS becomes f(a), while the RHS becomes the definition of the derivative of F(x) at a, which is the fundamental theorem of calculus!

Incidentally, adapting averages to continuous areas could be easier if you think of averaging as redistribution: you take some from the biggest number in a set and give it to the smaller ones, repeating until all are the same. Similarly, averaging an infinite set can be seen as reshaping it while conserving area until everything is the same height. This results in a rectangle; using the area formula and juggling stuff around gets you the average formula in an intuitive, geometric manner.

1:30
It seems to me that this is because, when approaching an average of a finite set of values, we have been drilled to treat it as the sum of the set over the number of terms - finding the mean of the set. This, in the cases that we've always seen in algebra, works perfectly fine, but is not the most general concept of an average. An average value is, most generally the "middle-est" value of a set - which, in the simple finite case, is very well described as a simple mean, but in finding the average of a continuous variable of course can't be approached the same way.

My point is this - the definition of an "average value" does not break down when asked about an infinite set, but rather asks you, the mathematician, to broaden your idea of what an average is. In any case, your video is exceptionally made as always. Thank you for the content.

I found another method to solve the average height of sin(x) between 0 and pi which i thought was interesting.
If you were to subtract the average height of sin (x) between 0 and pi from sin(x) so that f(x) = sin(x) - a, the area above and below the x axis between 0 and pi would be equal. Due to the fact that integral functions solve for signed area, integrating f(x) = sin (x) - a between 0 and pi, and equating to 0 allows to solve for a, giving you 2/pi.

There's an interesting intuition on averages that my 7/8th grade math teacher taught to me that you don't bring up at all that I figured I'd share! She wanted us to think of averages as redistribution: taking some amount away from the numbers with larger values and giving it to the smaller values until they're all the same.
It's a really useful intuition for understanding how outliers affect the average: they either add a significant amount to all the other values or take away a significant amount. it would also be useful as a shortcut in your intuition here of understanding the average of an area. if you imagine that area as being like a fluid in an odd shaped container, and you move it to a rectangular one, while keeping the same total area and width, the height of that rectangle would then be the average height.

anyways, that's just something that came to mind while watching this part that I thought I'd share. thanks for the great stuff!

For maximum enjoyment, take the equation at the top-left of 10:50 and ask what happens as you take (b - a) closer to 0. Well, on the left, you get the integral from a to almost-a of f(x), over a very tiny amount approaching zero; this ends up being just f(x). And on the right, you get the limit of (F(b) - F(a)) / (b - a) as (b - a) goes to 0, which is just the definition of dF(x)/dx. So f(x) = dF(x)/dx, exactly as expected!

I think about the average of a continuous variable as shaking up a bucket of sand until it levels. Since the amount of sand is constant, the area under the curve stays the same. New shape is a rectangle with the area being the base (interval length) times the height (average value). Therefore, the average is the integral divided by the interval length. This can be extended to multiple variables.

Hm. I find an argument for calculating the average somewhat better posited as asking the question: what value (so y=avg), integrated over the same range, yields the same area as integrating the original function.

ʃ f(x) dx = ʃ avg dx = avg * width (because we all know what the area of a rectangle is)
so clearly avg = ʃ f(x) dx / width

This is more of an algebraic argument, but in practice I find it more useful to think about. It also lets you think about sort of "compacting" the area under the original function into a simple rectangle, which I find quite satisfying.

Of course relating it to slope is a quite nice argument too, and thank you for your wonderful videos.

A good geometric explanation of "integral divided by width is the average height" is that you are putting a rectangle inside the integral bounds which has the same area as the integral. Then you take that rectangle area and divide by it's width to get it's height!
(a.k.a. you are trying to find out which constant function integrates to the same value)

Its nice that you also show this "interpretation" of integration, because it generalizes far better to curve integrals than the normal "area" intepretation

Hey, I really enjoyed your video, but I do have a question on my intuitive understanding of averages. I have kind of always thought about averages as "rearranging" in a sense. Like with the average of 1,4,5,2, I  could think of that as what number can I change all of those to and still have the sum remain the same. In that case the answer is 3 because 3+3+3+3=1+4+5+2. So when I later though about averages of functions, I thought okay, I can draw the average somewhere, and the same amount of stuff will be over it as under it. So the area of the rectangle where the interval is the width, when multiplied by the average value will equal the integral over that interval. I know it is true and if you buy into that you get the result in (basically 2 steps). But I don't know how I can rigorously justify my intuition going in to it. If anyone can help me with that, it would be greatly appreciated.
